title: Introduction to purloiner
text: purloiner consolidates calculates different sets time-series features multiple feature sets R Python. feature extraction useful, users consider using larger theft (Tools Handling Extraction Features Time series) package CRAN access entire workflow functions feature calculation, processing, visualisation, statistical analysis. purloiner feature calculation module theft.

title: Introduction to purloiner
text: explore package functionality, going calculate features basic dataset 2 time series: one generated Gaussian noise generated AR(1) process:
code: tmp <- data.frame(values = c(rnorm(100), arima.sim(model = list(ar = 0.8), n = 100))) tmp$id <- rep(c(1, 2), each = 100) tmp$group <- rep(c("Noise", "AR(1)"), each = 100) tmp$timepoint <- rep(seq.int(from = 1, to = 100, by = 1), times = 2)

title: Introduction to purloiner
text: core function automates calculation feature statistics extract_features. can choose subset features calculate feature_set argument. choices currently "catch22", "feasts", "Kats", "tsfeatures", "tsfresh", /"TSFEL". Note Kats, tsfresh TSFEL Python packages. R package reticulate used call Python code uses packages applies within broader tidy data philosophy embodied purloiner. present, depending input time-series, purloiner provides access \(>1200\) features.

previous_headings: Core calculation functions > Calculating feature summary statistics
title: Introduction to purloiner
text: Prior using purloiner (want use Kats, tsfresh TSFEL feature sets; R-based sets run fine) working Python 3.9 installation run function install_python_libs(python_path, path) first installing purloiner, python_path argument filepath location Python 3.9 machine path argument location wish install Python libraries virtual environment machine. example, wanted install Python libraries resulting virtual environment "C:/Users/User/Desktop/purloiner" Python 3.9 located "/usr/bin/python" machine, run following first installed purloiner: want use Python-based packages, must first tell R Python /virtual environment computer contains installed libraries. can done purloiner via init_purloin function, two arguments: python_path – filepath version Python wish use (.e., entered install_python_libs ran first) venv_path – filepath Python virtual environment tsfresh, TSFEL, /Kats installed (.e., path returned console message install_python_libs ran function first) However, necessarily use convenience function. another method pointing R correct Python (reticulate findpython), can use workflow instead. NOTE: need call  init_purloin solution per session.

title: Introduction to purloiner
text: comprehensive comparison catch22, feasts, tsfeatures, Kats, tsfresh, TSFEL across range domains (including computation speed, within-set feature composition, -set feature correlations), please refer paper Empirical Evaluation Time-Series Feature Sets1.

title: Calculate Time-Series Features from Feature Sets in R and Python
text: purloiner software package R facilitates user-friendly access calculate  > 1200 time-series features range existing R Python packages. packages purloiner ‘steals’ features currently : catch22 (R; see Rcatch22 native implementation CRAN) feasts (R) tsfeatures (R) Kats (Python) tsfresh (Python) TSFEL (Python) Please note users consider using larger theft (Tools Handling Extraction Features Time series) package CRAN access entire workflow functions feature calculation, processing, visualisation, statistical analysis. purloiner become feature calculation module theft CRAN. Kats, tsfresh TSFEL Python packages. purloiner built-functionality helping install libraries—need install Python 3.9 machine. wish access Python feature sets, please run ?install_python_libs R downloading purloiner consult vignette package information. comprehensive comparison catch22, feasts, tsfeatures, Kats, tsfresh, TSFEL across range domains (including computation speed, within-set feature composition, -set feature correlations), please refer paper Empirical Evaluation Time-Series Feature Sets.

title: Compute features on an input time series dataset — extract_features
code: extract_features(   data,   id_var = "id",   time_var = "timepoint",   values_var = "values",   group_var = NULL,   feature_set = c("catch22", "feasts", "tsfeatures", "Kats", "tsfresh", "TSFEL",     "basicproperties"),   catch24 = FALSE,   tsfresh_cleanup = FALSE,   seed = 123 )

title: Compute features on an input time series dataset — extract_features
text: data data.frame least 4 columns: id variable, group variable, time variable, value variable id_var character specifying ID variable identify time series. Defaults "id" time_var character specifying time index variable. Defaults "timepoint" values_var character specifying values variable. Defaults "values" group_var character specifying grouping variable unique series sits (one exists). Defaults NULL feature_set character vector character denoting set time-series features calculate. Defaults "catch22" catch24 Boolean specifying whether compute catch24 addition catch22 catch22 one feature sets selected. Defaults FALSE tsfresh_cleanup Boolean specifying whether use -built tsfresh relevant feature filter . Defaults FALSE seed integer denoting fixed number R's random number generator ensure reproducibility. Defaults 123

title: Compute features on an input time series dataset — extract_features
text: object class feature_calculations contains summary statistics feature
